ranked_diseases.explanation: Down syndrome commonly presents with both clinodactyly (especially of the 5th finger) and characteristic facial features including flat facial profile, epicanthal folds, and upslanting palpebral fissures.
Russell-Silver syndrome frequently includes clinodactyly of the 5th finger and distinctive facial features such as triangular face, prominent forehead, and small chin.
CdLS type 1 presents with clinodactyly and characteristic facial dysmorphism including synophrys, long eyelashes, and distinctive facial gestalt.
RSTS1 features include broad thumbs/toes with possible clinodactyly and distinctive facial appearance with downslanting palpebral fissures and beaked nose.
This X-linked disorder can present with clinodactyly and characteristic facial features including hypertelorism, widow's peak, and broad nasal bridge.
Features include clinodactyly and facial abnormalities such as facial asymmetry, low frontal hairline, and ptosis, though craniosynostosis is more characteristic.
Turner syndrome can present with clinodactyly and facial dysmorphism including webbed neck, low posterior hairline, and micrognathia, particularly relevant given female gender.
FASD can present with clinodactyly and characteristic facial features including smooth philtrum, thin upper lip, and short palpebral fissures.
